title: Mobile Embedded Systems — Architecture, Power, and Communication
cue_questions: What distinguishes a mobile embedded system from a general-purpose computer?
Why is power management the most critical constraint in mobile embedded design?
What is the difference between bare-metal firmware and an RTOS?
How does Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) minimize power consumption?
What is sensor fusion and why is it useful?
Why should dynamic memory allocation be avoided in embedded firmware?
How does a dual-bank OTA update system ensure reliability?
notes: An embedded system is a specialized computing system for dedicated functions within a larger system; mobile embedded systems are portable and battery-powered.
Common examples include smartphones, fitness trackers, GPS devices, medical wearables, and automotive ECU modules.
Hardware architecture: microcontroller or application processor, SRAM/DRAM, flash storage, sensors, radios, displays, and actuators.
ARM Cortex-M is used for low-power wearables; ARM Cortex-A powers smartphones; RISC-V is an emerging open-source alternative.
Power management techniques: Dynamic Voltage and Frequency Scaling (DVFS) reduces clock speed and voltage when full performance is not needed.
Sleep modes (idle, standby, deep sleep) reduce current draw to microamps; deep sleep requires RTC or external interrupt to wake.
Bare-metal firmware runs directly on hardware without an OS — maximum control but difficult multitasking.
RTOS (FreeRTOS, Zephyr, Mbed OS) provides task scheduling, inter-task communication, and deterministic timing guarantees for real-time responsiveness.
Wireless protocols: BLE (short-range, low-power), Wi-Fi (local), LoRa (long-range, low-power), LTE-M/NB-IoT (wide-area cellular).
BLE uses 2.4 GHz band, short data bursts, and GATT profile for service/characteristic definitions.
Common sensors: accelerometer, gyroscope, GPS, temperature/humidity, heart rate/SpO2.
Sensor fusion combines multi-sensor data (e.g., IMU with Kalman filter) for more accurate orientation estimates.
Memory is severely limited (sometimes 64 KB RAM); avoid malloc/free fragmentation — use static allocation or memory pools.
OTA updates use dual-bank flash: new firmware downloads to secondary bank; bootloader rolls back on failure.
Security: hardware secure elements or TrustZone, TLS encryption, secure boot for firmware integrity verification.
summary: This lecture covered the fundamentals of Mobile Embedded Systems. These are constrained, battery-powered devices optimized for dedicated tasks under tight power, memory, and real-time requirements. Key topics included hardware architecture (ARM Cortex-M/A, RISC-V), power management via DVFS and multiple sleep modes, the choice between bare-metal firmware and an RTOS for deterministic task scheduling, wireless communication protocols with a focus on BLE, sensor integration and fusion using algorithms like the Kalman filter, disciplined memory management without dynamic allocation, dual-bank OTA firmware updates, and security best practices including secure boot and TrustZone.
